item.title: 2. File Permissions
item.description:
2. File Permissions

I would like any candidate to be able to tell me what the typical file permissions mean.

item.title: 4. Basic Understanding of Network Concepts
item.description:
4. Basic Understanding of Network Concepts

Having a basic understanding of networking fundamentals gives candidates the basis for expanding their knowledge into other, more advanced, areas; as they work on normal duties, for this position, and once they become an Admin.

item.title: 5. RAID
item.description:
5. RAID

Understanding RAID levels is important to understanding how our systems work.

item.title: 6. Being Able to Troubleshoot Common Applications
item.description:
6. Being Able to Troubleshoot Common Applications

You need to know where the logs are. AT LEAST THAT. If you can, try to get experience for what can be found in them. Familiarize yourself with their messages, errors, format, etc.

item.title: 7. Bash
item.description:
7. Bash

I think that it's essential that all candidates understand basic Bash and be able to write simple Bash scripts. I'm not looking for anything incredibly in depth here, but I do need to know that candidates have basic skills that they can work with.

item.title: 8. Understanding What Takes Place When a Computer or Server Boots
item.description:
8. Understanding What Takes Place When a Computer or Server Boots

Understanding this process provides a solid foundation for future learning, and it also shows me that somebody has taken the initiative in wanting to learn how things work under the hood.

item.title: 10. Linux Kernel
item.description:
10. Linux Kernel

The central module of an operating system. It is the part of the operating system that loads first, and it remains in main memory. Because it stays in memory, it is important for the kernel to be as small as possible while still providing all the essential services required by other parts of the operating system and applications. Typically, the kernel is responsible for memory management, process and task management, and disk management.

item.title: 9. Memory Information
item.description:
9. Memory Information

Swap is additional memory the server can use if the RAM has run out. Swap is much slower than RAM. So if you have a really high swap there must be something using up a lot of memory.
